title: 107_s2846
content: The Act may be cited as the "Security and Liberty Preservation Act". The Security and Liberty Preservation Act acknowledges the threat of terrorism post-9/11, leading to expanded government surveillance powers. Despite the need for security measures, Americans value individual rights and privacy protected by the Constitution. Different investigative methods can achieve security goals with varying impacts on rights. The government should conduct investigations and surveillance to address law enforcement and national security needs while preserving the personal dignity, liberty, and privacy of individuals in the United States. Establishment of Commission. The Commission on Enhancing Security and Preserving Freedom is established with 17 members, including representatives from the Federal Government such as the Attorney General, Secretary of the Treasury, Secretary of Commerce, Director of Central Intelligence, and Director of Homeland Security. The Commission on Enhancing Security and Preserving Freedom has 17 members appointed by various congressional leaders and government officials. Individual designees must hold a position in the US Government appointed by the President with Senate consent. The Commission on Enhancing Security and Preserving Freedom has 17 members appointed by congressional leaders and government officials. Requirements for appointees include at least one from a State law enforcement agency and one from a local law enforcement agency. No appointee can be from the Federal Government or an active member of the uniformed services. Members of the Commission on Enhancing Security and Preserving Freedom should have varying viewpoints and expertise in technology, non-profit entities, and academia. They will be appointed for the life of the Commission, and vacancies will be filled in the same manner as the original appointment. Each member appointed must possess a security clearance appropriate for the Commission's work. If an individual appointed to a position on the Commission without a security clearance fails to obtain one by the start of the Commission's work, the appointment is considered vacant. The Attorney General is responsible for ensuring timely processing of security clearance applications. The Commission shall select a Chairman from among its members and hold its first meeting within 30 days of appointing nine members. Meetings will be called by the Chairman, and a majority of members constitute a quorum for hearings. SEC. 4. DUTIES OF COMMISSION. The Commission will investigate standards for using investigative and surveillance technologies to meet law enforcement and national security needs while preserving personal dignity, liberty, and privacy. It will also consider establishing entities or procedures to ensure the protection of individuals' rights. A report is due within 18 months of the Commission's initial meeting. The Commission will submit a report to the President and Congress containing findings, conclusions, and recommendations for legislation and administrative actions regarding investigative and surveillance technologies. These technologies include Internet surveillance and data mining, used without reasonable suspicion of criminal activity. The Commission will report on various surveillance technologies, including Internet surveillance, data mining, surveillance cameras, x-ray body scans, biometrics, and other technologies for legislative and administrative actions. The Commission has powers to report on surveillance technologies for legislative and administrative actions. The Commission has the authority to conduct hearings, including public meetings, and closed meetings as needed for carrying out its responsibilities under the Act. The Commission may hold closed meetings under certain laws, including for national security reasons. The President can determine if disclosing certain matters could endanger national security, allowing for closed sessions. A public summary of closed proceedings must be provided. The Commission may hold closed meetings for national security reasons, with the President having the authority to determine if disclosure could endanger national security. A public summary of closed proceedings must be provided, including maintaining and making available unclassified summaries of classified information and meetings. Subpoenas issued by the Commission must bear the Chairman's signature and can be enforced through the United States district court in case of non-compliance. The Commission may issue orders for individuals to testify or produce evidence, with non-compliance punishable as contempt of court. Witness allowances and fees will be paid from Commission funds. Procedures for handling confidential information require joint approval by the Attorney General and Director of Central Intelligence. The Commission has the authority to obtain necessary information from federal agencies, use postal services, and accept gifts or donations of services or property. SEC. 6. COMMISSION PERSONNEL MATTERS. Members of the Commission serve without compensation. Travel expenses are provided for members while away from home. The Chairman can appoint necessary staff without following civil service laws. The Commission can hire additional personnel, including an executive director, whose compensation is determined by the Chairman without following certain federal pay regulations. The executive director and staff must have appropriate security clearances. The Commission can hire additional personnel without reimbursement, and the Chairman can procure temporary services as needed. Staff must have appropriate security clearances. The Commission will terminate 60 days after submitting its report. Funding for the Commission is addressed in Section 8. Funding for the Commission is authorized for fiscal years 2003, 2004, and 2005. If no funds are appropriated, the Secretary of Commerce will transfer necessary amounts. The funds remain available until expended.
